item.title: Afghanistan President, Ashraf Ghani, Blames ISIS for Deadly Suicide Bombing at Bank
item.description: If the Islamic State’s role is confirmed, the attack would be a major escalation of the group’s activities in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: KHALID ALOKOZAYand ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: People ran for cover after an explosion in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Germanwings Crash Exposes History of Denial on Risk of Pilot Suicide
item.description: Investigations have exposed a series of failures and weaknesses throughout the airline industry in dealing with mental illness among pilots.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KULISH and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Rescuers at the site of the Germanwings crash near Seyne-les-Alpes, France, on March 30, six days after the plane smashed into the ground.

item.title: Kabul Journal: At Afghan Weddings, His Side, Her Side and 600 Strangers
item.description: Strangers seeking banquet fare arrive in droves as many seem to know this saying: “With a wedding every night, there is no need to go hungry.”
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys in dinner suits played one Friday this month in a parking lot outside Mumtaz Mahal, a wedding hall in Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: Australian Police Arrest 5 Men They Say Were Planning Terror Attacks
item.description: Two of the men, both 18, had been preparing to attack police officers in Melbourne during a national holiday, the authorities said Saturday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Replica of Lafayette’s Frigate to Set Sail From France for a U.S. Visit
item.description: The full-size replica of the Hermione, which carried the Marquis de Lafayette to America in 1780, will visit several East Coast ports this summer.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Vivian Nicholson, Rags-to-Riches-to-Rags Icon, Dies at 79
item.description: Mrs. Nicholson was just 25 when she won a sports bet that paid more than £150,000, the equivalent today of about $4.5 million, and her life inspired a musical and a BBC television film.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Vivian Nicholson in 1961, after she and her husband won £152,300 predicting the outcomes of eight football matches.

item.title: Stanislav Gross, Czech Leader Who Erred on Iraq Link to 9/11, Dies at 45
item.description: A claim by Mr. Gross was the basis of the so-called Prague connection, an unsubstantiated allegation that linked the Sept. 11 attackers to Saddam Hussein’s regime, bolstering the case for invading Iraq.
item.dc:creator: JAN RICHTER
item.media:description: Stanislav Gross in 2009. At 34, he became his country’s youngest prime minister.

item.title: British Prosecutors Drop Charges Against 9 Journalists in Tabloid Inquiry
item.description: Those who will be spared prosecution over allegations that they paid officials for information include Andy Coulson, a former editor of The News of the World.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Referendum Reshapes Scottish Political Terrain
item.description: The Scottish National Party is expected to gain power in the national election on May 7.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mhairi Black, 20, center, is a Scottish National Party candidate for Parliament and is expected to defeat her Labour rival.

item.title: Obama Urges ‘Creative’ Talks to Bridge Divide With Iran on Sanctions
item.description: Iranian leaders have insisted in recent days that the sanctions be lifted as soon as a written accord is signed, a position that the country’s foreign minister reinforced on Friday.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Calls on Western Nations to Shelter Syrian Refugees
item.description: Not since the wave of people fleeing war in Vietnam have the world’s industrialized countries been under such intense pressure to share the burden of taking in refugees, experts say.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian refugees on their way to start the registration process after crossing into Jordan, at Zaatari Camp in 2013.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: TV Executives Are Questioned
item.description: Japan’s ruling party summoned executives from two leading television networks for questioning on Friday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Phone and Internet Lines Are Cut for a Delinquent Rio State
item.description: The state government of Rio de Janeiro, which is feverishly preparing for next year’s Olympic Games, has failed to pay its phone and Internet bills.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: 4 in British Navy Are Charged
item.description: Four members of the British Navy have been charged with sexual assault in connection with an attack that took place in Nova Scotia on April 10.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: India: Violent Protest in Kashmir
item.description: The police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse hundreds of demonstrators in Indian-controlled Kashmir on Friday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Open Source: Under Bombardment in Yemen, Civilians Voice Terror and Despair Online
item.description: As the Saudi-led air campaign in Yemen entered a fourth week, civilians shared anguished, close-up views of life during wartime on social networks.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Tibetan Dies After Setting Himself on Fire in Protest
item.description: The man, Nyi Kyab, 45, was protesting Chinese rule, said Free Tibet, an organization working for Tibet’s self-determination.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Yemeni Army Tries to Safeguard Oil Fields as Qaeda Fighters Advance
item.description: With no abatement to the fighting in Yemen, the United Nations and other aid agencies said the humanitarian crisis there was worsening.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: An airstrike hit the presidential palace, also known as the Republican Palace, in the southwestern city of Taiz, Yemen. The United Nations said 18 out of the country's 22 provinces have been hit by airstrikes.

item.title: Iran’s Foreign Minister Warns of Unlimited Atomic Fuel Enrichment if Talks on Final Agreement Fail
item.description: The language was unusually blunt about the consequences of Western powers choosing “the path of confrontation.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Serbian President’s Plane Takes Harrowing Plunge
item.description: No one on board was hurt during the minute-long dive, but the flight to Rome was sent back to Belgrade.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT
